trans-unit.source: Configuring the Network Server to handle connections

seg-source.mrk: Configuring the Network Server to handle connections

target.mrk: Configuring the Network Server to handle connections

trans-unit.source: You can configure the Network Server to use a specific number of threads to handle connections. You can change the configuration on the command line.

seg-source.mrk: You can configure the Network Server to use a specific number of threads to handle connections.
You can change the configuration on the command line.

target.mrk: You can configure the Network Server to use a specific number of threads to handle connections.
You can change the configuration on the command line.

seg-source.mrk: derby.drda.minthreads

target.mrk: derby.drda.minthreads

seg-source.mrk: derby.drda.maxthreads

target.mrk: derby.drda.maxthreads

trans-unit.source: The minimum number of threads is the number of threads that are started when the Network Server is booted. This value is specified as a property, derby.drda.minThreads=min. The maximum number of threads is the maximum number of threads that will be used for connections. If more connections are active than there are threads available, the extra connections must wait until the next thread becomes available. Threads can become available after a specified time, which is checked only when a thread has finished processing a communication.

seg-source.mrk: The minimum number of threads is the number of threads that are started when the Network Server is booted.
This value is specified as a property, derby.drda.minThreads=min.
The maximum number of threads is the maximum number of threads that will be used for connections.
If more connections are active than there are threads available, the extra connections must wait until the next thread becomes available.
Threads can become available after a specified time, which is checked only when a thread has finished processing a communication.

target.mrk: The minimum number of threads is the number of threads that are started when the Network Server is booted.
This value is specified as a property, derby.drda.minThreads=min.
The maximum number of threads is the maximum number of threads that will be used for connections.
If more connections are active than there are threads available, the extra connections must wait until the next thread becomes available.
Threads can become available after a specified time, which is checked only when a thread has finished processing a communication.

trans-unit.source: You can change the maximum number of threads by using the following command (all on one line):

seg-source.mrk: You can change the maximum number of threads by using the following command (all on one line):

target.mrk: You can change the maximum number of threads by using the following command (all on one line):

seg-source.mrk: java org.apache.derby.drda.NetworkServerControl maxthreads max [-h hostname] [-p portnumber

target.mrk: java org.apache.derby.drda.NetworkServerControl maxthreads max [-h hostname] [-p portnumber

trans-unit.source: You can also use the derby.drda.maxThreads property to assign the maximum value. A max value of 0 means that there is no maximum and a new thread will be generated for a connection if there are no current threads available. This is the default. The max and min values are stored as integers, so the theoretical maximum is 2147483647 (the maximum size of an integer). But the practical maximum is determined by the machine configuration.

seg-source.mrk: You can also use the <codeph>derby.drda.maxThreads</codeph> property to assign the maximum value.
A max value of 0 means that there is no maximum and a new thread will be generated for a connection if there are no current threads available.
This is the default.
The max and min values are stored as integers, so the theoretical maximum is 2147483647 (the maximum size of an integer).
But the practical maximum is determined by the machine configuration.

target.mrk: You can also use the <codeph>derby.drda.maxThreads</codeph> property to assign the maximum value.
A max value of 0 means that there is no maximum and a new thread will be generated for a connection if there are no current threads available.
This is the default.
The max and min values are stored as integers, so the theoretical maximum is 2147483647 (the maximum size of an integer).
But the practical maximum is determined by the machine configuration.

trans-unit.source: To change the time that a thread should work on one session's request and check if there are waiting sessions, use the following command (all on one line):

seg-source.mrk: To change the time that a thread should work on one session's request and check if there are waiting sessions, use the following command (all on one line):

target.mrk: To change the time that a thread should work on one session's request and check if there are waiting sessions, use the following command (all on one line):

seg-source.mrk: java org.apache.derby.drda.NetworkServerControl timeslice milliseconds [-h hostname] [-p portnumber]

target.mrk: java org.apache.derby.drda.NetworkServerControl timeslice milliseconds [-h hostname] [-p portnumber]

trans-unit.source: You can also use the <codeph>derby.drda.timeSlice</codeph> property to set this value. A value of 0 milliseconds indicates that the thread will not give up working on the session until the session ends. A value of -1 milliseconds indicates to use the default. The default value is 0. The maximum number of milliseconds that can be specified is 2147483647 (the maximum size of an integer).

seg-source.mrk: You can also use the <codeph>derby.drda.timeSlice</codeph> property to set this value.
A value of 0 milliseconds indicates that the thread will not give up working on the session until the session ends.
A value of -1 milliseconds indicates to use the default.
The default value is 0.
The maximum number of milliseconds that can be specified is 2147483647 (the maximum size of an integer).

target.mrk: You can also use the <codeph>derby.drda.timeSlice</codeph> property to set this value.
A value of 0 milliseconds indicates that the thread will not give up working on the session until the session ends.
A value of -1 milliseconds indicates to use the default.
The default value is 0.
The maximum number of milliseconds that can be specified is 2147483647 (the maximum size of an integer).
